column4: ok (sorry if i'm being irritating but this is slightly different again).. any ideas why i can sftp root@mydomain.com but not sftp myuser@mydomain.com ?
can you log in normally using ssh?
yes
try adding the -v switch, and seeing what sftp reports.
http://dpaste.com/91381/
what's your default shell upon login to that system?
bash
also, it was working till fairly recently.. i'm not sure what i've done except install flash media server :S
the target machine also runs ubuntu?
yeah
on the remote machine, what are the permissions for /dev/null?
try "sudo chmod 777 /dev/null", and try sftp again.
or 666, really
wow, that worked
thanks :D
(care to explain?)
sftp wants to write to /dev/null. that explains why root could use sftp, but your login couldn't.
what would have changed that?  it was working before..
and why does it want to write to /dev/null
(i don't know why sftp desperately needs to write to /dev/null :-)
